sentences.english: In the past few years, however, there has been an upsurge of research into the female sexual response.
sentences.chinese: 但在過去的幾年裏，對女性性反應的研究驟然升溫。

sentences.english: "When it happened to me, it was a shock, " the oncologist tells Terry Gross.
sentences.chinese: 此事驟然發生在我身上，這是一個震驚。

sentences.english: Here in New York, we’ve been catapulted into summer.
sentences.chinese: 在紐約，這裏已驟然入夏。

sentences.english: Markets have rallied very fast, but they fell just as quickly in the six months to March.
sentences.chinese: 市場在三月份前的的六個月裏乍然回暖又驟然降溫。

sentences.english: The fluctuating love disappears in the spring suddenly.
sentences.chinese: 浮浮沉沉的愛戀驟然消失在春天。

sentences.english: Bang floor is a , the gate of sickroom is shoved away.
sentences.chinese: 砰地一聲，病房的門驟然被推開。

sentences.english: Cold weather set in abruptly with a killing frost .
sentences.chinese: 下了一陣霜，天氣就驟然變冷了。

sentences.english: In consequence, the number of postmortems has fallen quickly.
sentences.chinese: 結果驗屍的數量驟然下降。

sentences.english: All at once there began to go a sort of bustle among the bulrushes;
sentences.chinese: 蘆葦叢裏驟然響起了一陣喧鬧聲。

sentences.english: The mercury dived to twelve below zero.
sentences.chinese: 溫度計的水銀柱驟然下降到零下十二度。

sentences.english: When to Eastern Han Dynasty, the hollow brick reduces suddenly, results in vanishes.
sentences.chinese: 東漢時，空心磚驟然減少，終至絕跡。

sentences.english: The cliff drops away at that point.
sentences.chinese: 在那個地點，懸崖驟然變得陡峭起來。

sentences.english: The temperature spurts in recent days.
sentences.chinese: 最近幾天，氣溫驟然上升。

sentences.english: The prices of the shares may ~ or plummet within one day.
sentences.chinese: 股票價格有可能在一天之內飛速上升或驟然下跌。

sentences.english: Take it away from this valley and you will see it fade like an echo.
sentences.chinese: 一旦離開這個峽谷，她就會像空谷迴音一樣驟然凋零。

sentences.english: There are some solid underlying reasons for the upward lurch in the price of raw sugar.
sentences.chinese: 粗糖價格驟然上漲有其深層次的合理原因。

definition: to cut open/to rip/to streak across (lightning, meteor etc)/to pierce (scream, searchlight etc)
lit. to drop from the sky (idiom)/fig. to appear unexpectedly/to arise abruptly/out of the blue/to drop into one's lap
to hold firmly, not let go
lit. hiding the sky and covering the earth (idiom); fig. earth-shattering/omnipresent/of universal importance
storm/violent commotion/fig. crisis (e.g. revolution, uprising, financial crisis etc)
